pages.text: Birgeria is a genus of Actinopterigian fish from the Triassic. Found in many locales around the world including Germany, Madagascar, Italy, Slovenia, China, Russia and North America, this large marine predator was quite successful for his time period.
Originally described by Louis Agassiz in 1844 as a species of Saurichthys, it would take an extra 75 years before Erik Stensi√∂ would recognize it as its own genus and erect it in 1919.

Able to reach 2 m in length, Birgeria was an offshore pelagic predator with a large mouth covered in teeth alternating in size and a long and strong body, practically scale-less if not for a small section towards the tail, covered in a small sheath of thin ganoid scales, which would provide rigidity to the top section of the tail.
